title: Will Senator Ron Johnson (R-WI) be re-elected this November?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
*This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
With 58% of precincts reporting, Johnson is leading with 52% vs Feingold 45%.

RCP poll average gives Feingold the lead by 3 pts. http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/wi/wisconsin_senate_johnson_vs_feingold-3740.html Marquette University poll:
Among likely voters, 47% support DEM Russ Feingold and 41% support REP Ron Johnson, with 8% lacking a preference. 
Among all registered voters, Feingold receives 46%, Johnson 40% and 11% lack a preference. 538 is giving Johnson only a 13.9% prob of winning: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/senate/wisconsin/

Marquette University poll: 
"In a head-to-head matchup for Wisconsin's U.S. Senate race, among likely voters, 47% support DEM Russ Feingold and 41% support REP Ron Johnson, with 8% lacking a preference. 
Among all registered voters, Feingold receives 46%, Johnson 40% and 11% lack a preference." RCP polling average gives Feingold the lead by 3 pts.
Feingold has carved out a small but tenacious lead in most polls and Democrats unexpected need (post-Comey) to refocus national resources on wisconsin as a firewall should boost feingold

Johnson has been relatively quiet in Wisconsin politics, failing to pull headlines away from the Governor. Feingold has relaxed his stance on outside funding, which significantly hampered his previous candidacy and maintains significant name recognition.
Polls have tightened up slightly.  Also, I think there will be down ballet consequences of Hillarys decreasing chances.  Still, Hillary's get out the vote machine makes Donald's look amateurish.
Based on 538's prediction. On an unrelated note, go go Russ Feingold!
Up 25% as a hedge since polling and fundraising seems not as lop-sided.

Dems are jittery and GJO consensus is overconfident. 
https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-kaine-head-wisconsin-elections-waning-days-144734003.html

There is a lot of outside money pouring in for Johnson, and that turns Wisconsinites off. Also; Johnson has done nothing but obstruct, and has offered very little as an alternative except for hollow rhetoric which has not gone unnoticed.

Too much bad blood after the riots and social unrest. Blame, as always had to be put on somebody on charge and many put it on Johnson. I don't believe he himself is so excited to run after the headaches he had in the recent past.
Polls and spillover from Clinton favour Feingold.

Most recent polls give Feingold a lead of as many as 5 pts:
 http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/wi/wisconsin_senate_johnson_vs_feingold-3740.html

This story is gaining popularity in WI: 
http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/13/feingold-talks-guns-clinton-tape/91997156/ All Johnson has to do (assuming he has enough money) is to distort it a bit and advertise heavily in Northern part of the state.
Johnson has gained a bit in the last two polls. Not sure what that means.
polls and consensus don't match at at all. My 15% is probably too low on Johnson

I decided to wade in here because it looked like the consensus of 5% was pretty unreasonable (and most of the people who have written explanations have mentioned that).  Always looking for an easy way to skim accuracy points.  After having gone through in some detail, I'm not sure consensus is actually all that far off. The race has clearly tightened, but Feingold looks to be a very strong favorite, and most of the trends seem to favor him more than Johnson. 1) Feingold has been ahead in every single poll in the race but one - http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/wi/wisconsin_senate_johnson_vs_feingold-3740.html#polls . It's true his lead has been narrowing, but it looks like he's still decently ahead w/ 3 wks to go. 2)  There are two debates - one just happened, and headline was "Johnson stands by Trump" ... not good.  http://www.startribune.com/johnson-feingold-to-debate-in-tightening-senate-race/397083991/ And http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/14/johnson-feingold-clash-first-debate/92090700/ 3) The reality is, this is going to be a turn-out game, and on this front I expect Feingold will have the edge over Johnson.  a) Clinton has been up in every poll in the state so far: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/wi/wisconsin_trump_vs_clinton-5659.html#polls . I'd expect as well that the lead has widened in the last wk, as it has everywhere else in country.  b) In Johnson's favor though, unlike the rest of the country, in wisconsin the "ground game" (as measured by field offices), is pretty evenly matched (http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/trump-clinton-field-offices/).  And those offices are apparently focused on him not Trump (according to article). He's an incumbent w/ a real organization and resources in a seat I'm sure the R's desperately want to hold on to. Johnson is clearly outperforming Trump, he has the resources he needs, and the race has tightened -- obviously he COULD win.  There is one more debate left, and a few wks for him to change the story from being all about Trump.   I'd put Trump's odds of carrying the state at ~5%. I'll give Johnson 2x better chance than Trump (so 10% chance).
Coming in at 44. Is there something I am missing? I wanted to go to 48 but got scared by consensus.

Polls have tightened recently.  I'm not sure if there is a single reason for the change, but some news articles point to the typical attacks that Feingold is a typical politician, accepts big money, etc.  It would be interesting if these attacks are the reason for the slide, given the fact that his name is on the biggest Federal campaign finance reform bill to pass since 1971. Anyway, there are two debates scheduled soon.  I am assuming that voter opinions are actually more stable than polls are, so big events such as debates will generally tend to move the polls back toward their average over the entire course of the campaign.  We saw this in the national race, so I wouldn't be surprised to see it here, though early polling is probably also less accurate in Senate elections where there is less media coverage of the candidates.
another poll has this now as a very close race. WTF is the consensus doing so slow still? http://talkingpointsmemo.com/polltracker/marquette-poll-wisconsin-senate-tightens

http://www.jsonline.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/10/12/marquette-poll-clinton-leads-trump/91896250/ Yes, Feingold is favorite to win but he is almost certainly not 20 times more favorite to win as the consensus here indicates.

http://thehill.com/blogs/ballot-box/300285-poll-gop-senator-takes-lead-in-key-senate-race Consensus at 5%? No reason to be that cocky.

Odds are looking terrible, and consensus has already buried the poor man.

Met Russ while boarding a plane today. Exchanged a few flattering back and forths. Basically, one of the few good guys with some solid convictions. He flew economy class. Turns out we live about one mile apart, his house in a neighborhood not appreciably different from mine (I am ~20%-ter, FWIW). The plane was nearly full and it wasn't a small plane, yet it appears that no one except me recognized him - even though ~everyone's final destination must have been our hometown. I'll have no issues with voting for him but he does have the entire problem of distressed economy in Northern WI to deal with. Plus, the increased danger of straight ticket voting in case Trump does better than expected. Increasing uncertainty as a contrarian vote in the face of what I view as overconfident consensus.

The honourable gentleman has never exactly been a treeful of owls, and he seems more flummoxed than usual these days.  He has been sitting on his cash because there is not much new money coming in; his adverts neglect to mention the fact that he is already a senator; and he has also apparently been misrepresenting his business history, much like his idol The Great And Powerful Oz.    Wisconsin is probably over its flirtation with Republicans anyway.  They do this periodically, and always manage to pick the worst Rs to hang around with--remember Joe McCarthy?  He followed Bob LaFollette the Younger, of course, but was immediately succeeded by a long parade of Ds in both Wisconsin seats until Johnson limped in and has been hiding under his desk for six years.  He beat Feingold in '10, but not gonna happen this time.  (In a couple of years, Governor Walker will be waving good-bye; he is not term-limited, but will not seek re-election as Gov because (a) he'd lose, and (b) he wants to run for Pres in '20 and needs to raise money and make friends, in either order.) http://www.progressive.org/news/2016/05/188740/senate-historian-removes-ron-johnsons-big-lie-official-bio

Former Sen. Feingold has held a double-digit advantage in all polls since April. That would be hard to overcome if the top of the ticket wasn't anathema to the Republican establishment of the state.  But Mr. Trump is, as witnessed by their avoidance of his recent rally in Green Bay.  There are no coattails for Sen. Johnson to ride, and his record provides little to cheer about. . . . 
"The Johnson campaign should be happy that they're outperforming the presidential candidate," said poll director Charles Franklin. "On the other hand, outperforming someone who is doing as poorly as Trump is doing right now is a real disadvantage to the campaign. . . . the most important thing about the presidential race in its effect on the Senate race is how it drives voter turnout. With Wisconsin being a high turnout state, even marginal shifts in turnout among Republicans and Democrats can sway the final results of down-ballot races.
. . . 
"One silver lining in the poll for Johnson is he leads Feingold among independents by 44% to 42%. Ninety-two percent of Democrats say they'll vote for Feingold and 87% of Republicans back Johnson. "In a three-way race that includes Libertarian candidate Phil Anderson, Feingold had 47%, Johnson 38% and Anderson 7% among registered voters. While standing in opposition to "overregulation," Johnson fails to take even a nuanced approach to address citizen grievances. A better approach might be: "We don't need new regulation. We just need to do a better job of enforcing existing regulation." Instead, he ignores the real concerns of Wisconsin citizens. (He also ignores basic family dynamics, which while evolving, still likely exhibit fairly traditional patterns in many rural areas. Forgive me if I sound sexist on this, but if Wisconsin has a lot of small "family farms," while the Johnson "fear of additional costs" message may appeal to the (predominantly) men who run the business-side of those farms, "the water is dangerous for our children" message may have stronger appeal to the female who likely runs the family-side of those farms.)

Passage of time and continuing large leads for Feingold in the polls.

Will Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnson be re-elected against former Senator Russ Feingold in November? Outside View:
PredictIt: 17%
Predictwise: 30%
Average outside view: 24% Polling:
Feingold leads by an average of 11% in polls, last 2 polls have him up by 9% and 13% respectively (http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-wisconsin-senate-johnson-vs-feingold). Feingold has been ahead since the start of the year (by around 7% in January). The polls are therefore not good for Ron Johnson. Feingold is also consistently reaching 50% with only a small amount of undecided (likely to reflect that both candidates are fairly well-known with voters having already made up their minds). 
Overall: The polls at this stage (and for most of the year) are very bad for Johnson, he is a long way behind and seems to have little incumbency advantage. The only question is the amount of time left in the race, however Johnson will have to begin making up ground quickly. 30% Money/Campaign quality:
In February the two candidates had a similar amount of money on hand (http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/big-names-filling-ron-johnsons-russ-feingolds-coffers-b99672922z1-369600651.html) however Johnson may have some advantage in PAC contributions (not sure how much difference this makes) and Feingold outraised Johnson up to April (http://fox6now.com/2016/04/12/ron-johnson-outraised-by-russ-feingold-emboldened-by-primary-results/). 
Overall: As usual this is fairly even with no real advantage either way Candidate quality:
Both candidates are quite well-known (ie. the challenger is not some untested campaigner). Johnson has higher unfavourables than Feingold (http://www.americansunitedforchange.org/page/-/WisconsinResults616.pdf) but this is not particularly surprising as an incumbent.
Overall: Again these are two fairly strong candidates who are unlikely to damage themselves during the campaign so call it a wash National effect:
The national election is likely to have an impact on this race. Trump seems particularly unpopular in Wisconsin (he lost to Ted Cruz convincingly during the primary). We known that down-ticket races are becoming increasingly nationalised and even more so during presidential cycles (http://fivethirtyeight.com/datalab/the-2014-senate-elections-were-the-most-nationalized-in-decades/). Again, I think the impact of Trump can be overstated and its possible for some Republican incumbents to hold their own (Rob Portman in Ohio for example). However, Trump is down significantly to Clinton in general election polls (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/wisconsin/) with large disapproval ratings. All the evidence then suggests that Trump is and will likely continue to be a drag on Johnson’s chances. The one upside for Johnson in this area is that it is unlikely that Trump can fall much lower in Wisconsin, in a sense this may be the lowest point for Johnson’s chances, the question is whether he can improve them at all.
Overall: -5% Current Prediction: 25% If this election were being held a month today then the prediction would likely be closer to 95% (a 10 point gap is just that bad), but the main variable here is time. There is still time for Johnson to drag it back and indeed it seems likely that he will eventually narrow the gap at least a little bit. Clearly if polling evidence (either local or national) begins to change then the prediction will, but if a sizeable gap remains then it will be very hard for Johnson to win. I’m also interested in the discrepancy between my prediction (25% likelihood), which is in line with 538’s early prediction (15% likelihood), and the classification of the race as a toss-up by Cook Political. I think the difference stems from my polling-centric approach and their more fundamental-centric approach. They clearly see a Republican incumbent in a swing-state as generally having a good chance. I’m open to this approach (and can definitely see how I might be too low of Johnson’s chances) but I think the evidence (at this point) is just too weighted in favour of Feingold. Will keep a close eye on this race though.
While he is the incumbent, he's trailing behind in the two polls in June (>10% average),  and in seven pools held since January (>10% average).

My Brexit's lesson: 
1- When i forecast something, when it is a close one (Johnson is an incumbent, it is an advantage), i should not make my forecast very far from the polls;
2- For me,  when i do so, it is hard to me, to change my mind radically, because in fact, nothing have change radically. 
______
3- Nate Silver, have written in his book, The signal and the noise (page 63) that 
an  advantage of :
5 points six months before an election have 66%;
5 points three months before an election have 72%;
10 points six months before an election have  79%
10 points three months before an election have 87%
There is 128 days before the election (4,2 months)

Russell touts a pair of polls released last week showing Feingold leading Johnson . . . . Now adding Trump – who couldn’t win the Republican primary in Wisconsin – only adds to the degree of difficulty. For some GOP incumbents, the 2016 vote means contending with their Democratic rivals while also worrying about being dragged down by the man poised to be at the top of the Republican ticket in November. “It was always going to be a tough race for Johnson because of the nature of our electorate in Wisconsin,” Sykes said in an interview. “And, obviously, the Trump thing complicates things.”

COMMENT:  Nothing that the Johnson campaign is doing seems to be working.  Polling in this race has been pretty consistently favorable for Feingold.   The crowd is very negative about Johnson's re-election chances, but having just seen the UK vote to leave the EU, I'm cautious about predicting elections.

http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate
Predictwise gives Johnson a 30% chance, whereas PredictIt has him at 15% (Predictwise gives weight to the "fundamentals" such as the incumbency factor). I continue to take the average of the two, and am consequently down 5% compared to last month.

Changing to 15 percent.  Essentially, no change.  Reason for 15% is that my previous guess of 13% insinuates precision that just isn't there.  This really has one and a half digits of precision.  The Cook Report still has Wisconson as Undecided - and I greatly respect Cook.  On the other hand, Johnson has been behind in the polls every single poll listed on Wikipedia.  If ya wanna win, ya gotta poll reasonably well.  And Trump.  Enough said. http://cookpolitical.com/senate/maps https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Wisconsin,_2016

This is just an early placeholder forecast based on current polls putting Feingold up mid single digits and the fact he is already a household name and strong challenger for an incumbent that doesn't get much press and hasn't done anything particularly notable while in office.  Trump's extremely high unfavorables will also work again Johnson on the margins.

While WI is a 50/50 state, the baggage that Feingold carries from his prior years is harmful to his election run at this point in time.  Ron Johnson has been reasonable in his efforts and advertising.
I consider him to be vulnerable and a top Democratic target.  Presidential election results could matter, but it will be close either way.

Losing every single poll, alarmingly high disapproval ratings, a perception of being too close to Mitch McConnell (12% in WI have favorable view of McConnell), and the top of the ticket. It will take something special to beat Feingold, but luckily for Johnson, there is a slight chance of that happening. The Republican Party in Wisconsin is a beast in terms of infrastructure, Republican primary turnout was unusually high, and voters are in the mood for an outsider. It's unlikely that he'll win, but there is a slight chance.

Sen. Johnson will get no help from the top of the ticket; Mr. Trump is not popular in America's Dairyland.  Driving through the state on I-94 last month, I saw no roadside signs supporting him.  (I did, however, see a few indicating that one President Clinton had been more than enough.) Sen. McConnell isn't helping, either.  The argument for a Republican-held Senate to stop Pres. H. Clinton's initiatives would play well beyond Dane County (Madison)... if the messenger wasn't also at least tacitly supporting the presumptive nominee. But he his. This leaves Sen. Feingold with the strategic advantage. A vote for him may provide a Constitutional barricade against Pres. Trump's crazier notions.  Sen. Feingold was generally well-regarded before his defeat, and the Tea Party/anti-Obama sentiment that put Sen. Johnson in office has faded with time and serial disappointment. Republicans who cannot part with the party completely may choose to hedge their bets by voting against Clinton and for Feingold.

Here's an opportunity for Johnson to break from the GOP establishment and distinguish himself: "... federal agents will continue to operate under a 30-year-old law known as the Electronic Communications Privacy Act that allows them to read email at will if the mail is at least six months old."
http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2016/06/09/senate-derails-bill-rein-email-surveillance/85641196/ This is a simple issue, understandable by even the most reclusive Wisconsin dairy farmer. No one wants to have their private communications snooped upon without a warrant. +1 on the long-shot that Johnson will do *something* to distinguish himself from the GOP status quo.

Predictions here seem overconfident for Feingold, given polling (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/wi/wisconsin_senate_johnson_vs_feingold-3740.html). I'm visiting Wisconsin right now. Mostly Trump and some Sanders signs visible in northern and central Wisconsin, and only Johnson commercials (which are smart enough to appeal to the Wisconsin ethos of avoiding serious negative campaigning about the opponent) on TV. Not as much of a slam dunk as people seem to think because HRC is NOT popular here. I'd be even higher on Johnson if it weren't for the willingness of Wisconsin voters to vote for one party for President and another for Senator.

PredictWise gives Russ Feingold 65% chance, which implies Ron Johnson only has a 35% chance. I find the consensus odds here unbelievably low, and suggest partisan bias as the explanation.

Ron Johnson introduces bill to tackle government waste
http://www.jsonline.com/news/statepolitics/ron-johnson-introduces-bills-to-tackle-government-waste-b99733187z1-381019641.html It's so sad. I like Ron Johnson. It's just that he's been in over his head in the Senate. He is not cut out to play the game of hardball politics the way it's played within the Beltway. His current legislative proposal is a good example. What might sound good to a naive accountant as an efficiency measure ("the bill would improve federal property management and establish a board to reduce the size of the government's property inventory"), will more than likely be converted into an efficient vehicle for sweetheart deals by the ravenous hounds in DC. One need only to look back a bit to see how the disposition of federal property went after the Conrail bustout, er bankruptcy, and the S&L "resolutions." If I'm not mistaken, a particularly sweet parcel from the Conrail divestiture ended up with Donald Trump. To cobble together these proposals into a single bill is just so mediocre. Any number of the more reasonable items could be added as an amendment to any other bill. In fact, Johnson would be better served just taking that Social Security Administration death master file proposal and offering it up as an amendment to every single bill he can. He needs to do something strong and decisive. This bill is not it, and he's running out of time. (-2)

Latest polls show declining gap, and with so many months to November I see voters having plenty of time to rewire their synapses.

This is going to be a close race this time just as it was back in 2010 when he just barely edged out Democrat Russ Feingold by 51.86% to 47.02%.  2010 was a year in which Democrats took "a thumping" by Republicans, and it was a time when the USA was still trying to climb back from the "Great Recession" which followed the Financial Crisis of 2007-2008.  Much as improved since those times.  Currently the unemployment rate Nationwide is holding at 5% (down from it's peak of of 10% during the Financial Crisis), whereas Wiscosin's unemployment rate is lower at 4.5% (which bodes well not only for the Democrat occupying the White House, but also for Democrtic challenger Russ Feingold.

Ron Johnson was a mediocre candidate who caught the wave of a historically Republican year and he's done nothing since to endear himself to Wisconsin voters.  Now he's stuck in a rematch with Russ Feingold, who, while far from a conventional politician, has a prior history and an existing relationship with Wisconsin. All polling suggests that Feingold has a measurable lead at this point in the race, and national resources are being committed on his behalf. This is a Presidential year with increased turnout, and Donald Trump at the top the ticket does no favors to Johnson. Russ, however, never really connected with a large swath of Wisconsin voters, as his election margins have been far from overwhelming. And Wisconsin Democrats recent record has been underwhelming compared to their supposed numerical strength, particularity against incumbents.  I'm fairly confident of a Feingold victory, but there are too many uncertainties in this race to call this "Bob Casey in 2006" over yet.
Big voter turnout in presidential election year. Clinton is consistently polling higher than Trump in Wisconsin.
Feingold is ahead in the polling in Wisconsin and enjoyed a good reputation when he held the Senate seat.

Trump factor makes it tough for WI Republicans (remember, Cruz won big here). And (perhaps a bit of wishful thinking on my part), Wisconsin has recovered from Walkerism and remembers what a great Senator they had in Russ Feingold.

https://badgerherald.com/opinion/2016/05/02/print-53-wisconsin-democrats-have-no-reason-to-be-excited-for-2016/ This Democratic writer is not optimistic that this seat can be flipped to Democrat.  Reasons he gives are:
-the recent string of Republican victories in WI ( U.S. Senate seat, three gubernatorial elections, two attorney general elections and control of the Assembly and Senate)
-passage of voter ID laws in WI which suppress the D vote, especially liberal D
-Koch Bros $10m+ and counting invested in R campaigns
-weakening of unions and their funding for D campaigns
-Trump & Cruz are seen as 2 peas in a pod--not divisive--for  WI Rs
-the WI R party is united:  even though Gov Walker has only a 40% approval rating, among Rs it's 80% These sound like good arguments to me.   Also, I am losing confidence in the D ability to win the WH because of Sander's strength.   Decreasing forecast for Johnson non-relection from 17 to 20%.

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/22/us/politics/with-uncertainty-at-top-of-ticket-republicans-back-off-in-some-states.html?emc=edit_th_20160422&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 "The Republican National Committee is scaling back its financial commitments to some of the most hotly contested states because of flagging fund-raising . . .  the committee’s chief strategist, acknowledged this week that the committee had begun informing state parties and statewide campaigns that fulfilling such plans [to provide field organizers]  would now be “slower.” . . . 
"Just as revealing, the party is also taking steps to create a separate fund-raising entity dedicated to Senate races, an acknowledgment that many of the wealthiest contributors are increasingly focused on protecting Republican control of Congress rather than on a presidential campaign they fear is lost.
. . . 
" . . .  worrisome to many veteran Republicans . . .  is what his [Trump's] nomination could mean for the party’s prospects across the board this fall. Mr. Trump has no high-dollar donor network and has given little indication that he is willing to tap into his fortune to give the party the hundreds of millions of dollars it will require to finance its campaigns in the fall.
. . .
"In the 2012 elections, the R.N.C. raised more than $409 million. The party has raised $135 million this election, but what is deeply concerning to many Republican candidates, contributors and strategists is that it only had a little more than $16 million on hand, along with nearly $2 million in debt, at the end of March. Mr. Spicer stressed that this was partly because the committee had already begun paying to send staff members to battleground states, well ahead of the same time four years ago. "But the party’s modest cash availability underscores how much hangs in the balance with its nominee. The minute Trump gets the nomination, the party is going to have to raise another three or four hundred million,” said Al Hoffman, a Florida-based Republican donor. . . .  Mr. Hoffman, a former R.N.C. finance chairman, . . .  said he had little appetite to raise money for a Trump-led party and would probably focus his efforts this year on helping a local House candidate and assisting the re-election of his friend, Senator John McCain of Arizona. And he emphasized that he was not alone. “All the donors I’ve talked to have said they want to sit out the presidential and just focus on the Senate and House,” Mr. Hoffman said. "Ray Washburne, a Republican fund-raiser from Dallas who also previously served as a national committee finance chairman, said, “There’s a big switch to doing the Senate races and trying to hold onto the Senate.” "Mr. Washburne said Mr. Trump, who has relied on mostly small-dollar contributors in addition to about $36 million of his own money, showed no sign of being prepared for the fund-raising demands of a presidential general election. “The Trump group has done nothing about putting together a finance team at all,” he said.  . . .  even as donors have asked him . . . how they could help Mr. Trump. “I don’t even know who the hell to tell them to call,” Mr. Washburne said. "This sort of unease about Mr. Trump, along with the dislike many of the party’s business-oriented donors have for the hard-line Mr. Cruz, has prompted the R.N.C. to begin privately assuring donors that it will create a so-called Senate Trust fund. Money earmarked for that fund will go entirely to initiatives aimed at retaining the Senate — including hiring field operatives and opposition researchers and bolstering digital efforts. . . . 
~~~~~~~

Yes, Gov. Walker has survived sit-ins at the Capitol and a recall election. Yes, he was unquestionably important to Sen. Cruz's thumping of Donald Trump in the Republican presidential primary. But, no matter how many campaign appearances he makes, pulling Sen. Johnson across the finish line will be a bridge too far. This is 2016, not 2010.  This election will not be a mid-term referendum on Barack Obama, the Tea Party is no longer ascendant, and, most importantly, Gov. Walker is not on the ticket. There are no coattails for Senator Johnson to grasp. The top of the ticket may, in fact, be radioactive to a significant portion of the Republican electorate. Even the threat of another Clinton in the White House may not be enough to motivate voters who feel that their strongly expressed preference was not heeded (take your pick, this will describe Cruz or Trump supporters). Every one that declares a pox on all candidates and stays home will be  worth his or her weight in campaign contributions to former Sen. Feingold, who was generally well thought of before his defeat.
